 No. Unions fought like hell to stop the practice of employers providing helth care. 
 
 The American tradition of employers providing health care started during WWII as a way for companies to get around federal wage caps.
 
 At the end of the war companies kept it in place because at the time health care was cheap, the cost to the companies was cheap (less than 1% of labor cost), but it provided a perceived benefit to the employee that was far greater than the cost. 
 
 Unions following WWII opposed the practice and tried to have it outlawed because they said it distorted wages. They preferred a simple wage model...not this XXXX where part of the compensation was health care that the union could not take a piece of in dues. 
 
 Even the claim that unions were responsible for the 8 hour work day are not exactly right. The 8 hour work day was created in 1937 with the passage of the Fair Labor Standards Act. The thing is, the Fair Labor Standards Act only passed because the 8 hour workday was already the norm for over 90% of American workers. 
 
 The 8 hour workday is attributable to Henry Ford. In 1914 there was an accident on the assembly line caused by a worker who had fallen asleep at their station. The norm prior to that time was for people to work 12-15 hours a day. Ford sat down with his managers and they decided that it would be better to run 2 shifts at 8 hours each than to run 1 long shift. The problem, of course, is that the hourly wage his people made would not cover their living expenses in only an 8 hour day, so Ford made the decision to double their pay. 
 
 The move was VERY unpopular with rival companies, but in the next year Fords productivity shot through the roof and their profit margin DOUBLED. Other companies took note of this and adopted the practice with similar results. IT turns out that working people until they are dead on their feet is very bad for productivity. Who knew?
 
 Anyway, the point is that by the time unions won their great "Victory" in 1937, virtually all US workers were already working 8 hours a day, 40 hours a week.

Less strife = less need for unions, so they have a tendency to work in such a manner that increased friction between companies and the workers they "represent".

This was not a job that came with a 6 figure salary like today. It was an unpaid, volunteer position. Their union leadership worked right there on the factory floor with them every day. Roughly once a month, there would be a meeting between the union leadership and the management. Most places they sat down for a meal. They would discuss labor issues at the factory where they all worked. 
 
 Today the way it works, the union "leaders" are all paid very well to be union leaders. Unions are no longer centralized around a particular factory, or even a particular industry. It is an INTENSELY adversarial process because the union representative is negotiating not just the workers pay, but by proxy they are negotiating the unions income. Their job is to suck as much as they possibly can out of management regardless of consequences. 
 
 The union system is broken. I support 100% unions when they exist as rational entities (you still see this in many european countries). As they are in the US, where they are a business in and of themselves, I think they should be outlawed.
